tweet: I define summer here as a month that has an average temperature of 70°F or warmer. June became a summer month in 1979, while October joined the season in 1998. It'll be awhile before May joins.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
March is the new May! 

Much like October and August, the average temperature in March has exceeded the average temperature May was 114 years ago in Pasadena, CA.

Summer has grown from 3 to 5 months long in Pasadena over the last 114 years. May will become a member in ~20 years. https://t.co/zRA5WQg7Sm

tweet:
It appears as though by June or July, the year-to-date anomaly is pretty close to that of what the annual anomaly is +/- a degree. 

April may end up giving another kick to 2022's average anomaly at a time when it should be falling. That would be no bueno. 3 100°F days do that.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
You can see in both how 2022 is in 3rd place. This will allow me to keep track of what place 2022 will end up being in.

Year-to-date anomalies tend to fall in spring and rise in fall. Yes, I am aware of the irony. The reason being is that Sept/Oct are the fastest warming months.

tweet:
@WhiskerKenbrook @BradleyWhitford Kind of, but note that California is the land of microclimates.

It snow regularly 4 miles north of this station, but almost never snows here.

The average high 20 miles WSW of us in summer is 24°F cooler.

Comparing stations in microclimate heavy regions isn't very helpful.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
@LoveDaVeggies @BradleyWhitford I am not yet a climatologist, but I can say this:

California's climate tipped for the worse in 2012 or so, and since then we've undergone every type of natural disaster in much quicker succession than before. 2013/14/15 drought, 2017 floods, 2020 heat/fires, 2021 drought.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
@WhiskerKenbrook @BradleyWhitford No, I don't know what is causing the sudden volatility at the end. For 60s years from the 1950s to the early 2010s, the avg temp NEVER ranged more than 2° from the trendline.

Suddenly, winters 2014 and 2015 were 4°/5° above the trendline, while 2018 and 2019 were 3°F below. Why?

2022 is off to a hot start w/ the first 3 months coming in 9.4°F above the early 20th century avg. Only '14 and '15 were hotter.

tweet:
April's average hottest day in Pasadena is now on average 5.6°F hotter than it was 114 years ago.

This heatwave should have only produced a high of 93°F. Instead, we reached 98°F.

32/43 (74%) of the April's since 1980 are above the trendline, so this stat is accelerating. https://t.co/jlXUAelBmx https://t.co/yhbPUexvEQ

tweet: @WinterPollan Only with heatwaves. The larger scale the feature, the longer forecasting range it has. A rainstorm has only 1-7 days of forecasting range as it is a smaller event. A mountain wave windstorm has a 3 day forecast range. Thunderstorms can be in the hours range.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
Do not put any merit into this. This is a 06z model run at 300+ hours. Note that while forecast models are good at forecasting heatwaves in the long term, they are NOT great at the location of them. Things move around. 

April, May, and June are forecasted to be hot by the CPC.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
I should not tweet this as it is too far out. I shouldn't.

However, because heatwaves are large scale features, forecast models can see them coming from pretty far out.

name: Edgar McGregor

tweet:
The hottest day in May used to be ~4°F warmer than the hottest day in April.

But that was 100 years ago. Since 2015, every April has seen higher temperatures than the following May.

Soon, April will overtake May in both monthly maximum AND average high. Thanks, @elamarinelayer

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
With the first 100°F days of summer now in the forecast for L.A., let's take a look at April monthly record maximums.

In Pasadena, 100°F highs in April have occurred 4 times; 1910, 1989, 2004, 2009, and soon 2022.

The average April monthly maximum has risen 5°F since 1909!😬 https://t.co/zxbKlh0kJ5

This particular tree, named Sol, was one of my favorite. She wanted to explode in size, and she did.

Then someone yanked her up. Brought it home, watched her die. Depressing time.

3 weeks later that little blip appeared at the trunk.

9 months later and she's 3 feet tall. https://t.co/Hix7imLT2r

Young saplings of this native tree species can no longer survive our increasingly hot summers, which are already 4-6 months long in southern California. 

I can find plenty of trash in my park, but no baby western sycamores outside the destructive flash flood zone.

tweet:
Today's official 90°F high in Pasadena, CA will very likely be the March 2022 monthly maximum. It is above the trend-based average.

The average hottest temperature observed each March has risen from 84°F to 88°F over the last 114 years.

March 1916 still holds the 98°F record. https://t.co/2BoyRtTdSZ

tweet: That graphic also perfectly illustrates how while August, followed by July are the 2 hottest average months of the year, September is the most prone to heatwaves.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
If you look at spring, you can see that April 6th has a daily record high of 105°F from 1989. 

Because of that event, we know the March monthly record high of 98°F from 1916 is very, very vulnerable.

100°F is easily achievable in March, we just haven't had the heatwave yet!

tweet:
In Pasadena, CA, a high temperature of 85°F is possible at any time of year.

Here is a look at the entire year's daily record highs.

I created a graph like this 1/2 a decade ago and finally got around to updating it tonight. Green numbers broke their daily record high in 2022. https://t.co/f3H9Cl1bKA

My park was among those that got left out. Still at 0.30" for the 2022 calendar year. 2nd driest start on record in 114 yrs.

Average for the Jan-Mar period is over 1 foot of rainfall. Thankfully, 12-26" came crashing down in 18 days in December, so we're fine through next Fall.

Next week's warm spell in California will allow an addition 4-6 days over 85°F in my part of L.A.

This would put us up to 14 days >=85°F so far this year. In 114 years of weather record keeping, only 2014 had more by the end of March with 20.

Annual count of 85°F days are⬆️😬! https://t.co/Hk893TKvi5

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
On April 5, 1989, temperatures were 100°F - 106°F across the L.A. Basin. To this day, it remains the hottest spring heatwave ever.

After 33 years of climate change and strengthening UHI, I'd sure that those temps are now climatologically possible in the last week of March.

@stevebloom55 There is a short term drought being overlayed onto a long term one. Essentially this means the long term drought was weakened, but the ecological recovery that was made is once again being lost.

Ex: 2021 was dry, December was wet, but December gains being lost to dry Jan/Feb/Mar

Hot... dry... windy. https://t.co/OxKTe0vIrR

tweet:
The West depends on it's winter precipitation in order to weaken drought conditions.

In 2013, the peak of the drought conditions 2022 is compared to were happening in late summer/autumn. This time around, we're EXITING the rainy season at this state.

Expect a crushing summer.

12. Keep going. A bucket a day. Get fresh air. Get exercise. Get outdoors. Leave the house. Meet new people. Discover new parks. Learn new plants/animals. Get injured. Invite your friends. Stand between your park and those who are negligent towards it.

12. Be a climate activist.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
8. Take responsibility of a certain area. Expect new litter, do not worry about litterbugs.

 9. Learn how to clean. Be thorough. Slow down. Check areas frequently. Go where you think there isn't litter; THERE IS!

10. Post about it. Talk about it with friends/family/coworkers.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
5. Just try it on Saturday. If you can manage Sunday, go then too. 

6. If after a few weeks you think you can manage weekdays, attempt a few. You don't need to be consistent like me. 

7. Talk to locals. Ask if they know other spots that need some love.

1. Buy three 5-gallon buckets at your local supply store. 
2. Buy a nice pair of gloves. I recommend: 
https://t.co/ciZAQQVFzv

3. Keep 1 bucket in the shower to catch cold water before it warms.
4. On weekends, take the others out to your local park and see what you can fill.

@Climatologist49 @AlaskaWx You know what might be a better indicator of current monthly warming rate? The number of years over the last 15 above the trend-based average. For example. November at 12/15 being above is a sign it is accelerating. 

For May, 6/15 means it it may be slowing down. https://t.co/8VKsDkrbLB

tweet:
Last month, the trend-based average temperature for February in Pasadena, CA crossed 60.00°F.

In the early 1900s, six months of our year had an average temperature of 60°F or greater. Today, it is TEN!

November reached it in 1940.
April in 1941.
March in 1992.
February in 2022. https://t.co/SHEDDWXNbH

This was after our 3rd wettest December ever.

#ClimateWhiplash

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
A single dry winter has a big environmental impact for CA, but not a long lasting one.

Two ultra dry winters in a row is cataclysmic, kills millions of trees, and can be seen in the fossil record.

2013-2014 were those 2 dry winters.
2021-2022 were this close to being one aswell

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
But in all seriousness I cannot stress how important those 11" were. 

An ultra dry winter (>8.0") has happened 5 times since 1909. The chance of two happening back-to-back is <1%.

I'm 21. I've been alive for 4 of the 5 driest years on record. Those back-to-back odds are rising.

Over the last 22 months, Pasadena has picked up 19" of rainfall.

Of those 19 inches, *11* of them fell in just 18 days between 12/14 and 12/31, 2021.

Since then, a near total shutout.

Climate scientists warned CA precipitation would become more variable. Here is exhibit A: https://t.co/q0xvYYarZQ

tweet:
Yesterday morning will likely be the coldest morning of winter 2022 for SoCal.

Sadly for Pasadena, the official low of 38°F is above even the trend-based average.

The average coldest morning of winter has warmed from 26.8°F to 36.2°F over the last 114 years, a +9.4°F change. https://t.co/ibmjJt8p3U

tweet:
This inlet is protected by two out cropping of rock with an island in between them. Waves meet inside a large pool about 50ft by 50ft. When a set arrives, it fills the pool enough to send a bore-like tidal wave into the inlet. 

This was an hour later... much lower tide. https://t.co/4WuaBLv9kK

tweet:
There is no greater sign of climate change than biome changes.

This is Big Pine Mountain in Santa Barbara County, CA.

The 2007 #ZacaFire torched this area hard, killing these 300yr old+ Ponderosa Pines.

Sadly, the pines have been unable to reestablish. Not so Big Pine anymore. https://t.co/V70bMne5Jl

tweet:
Pasadena's hail/sleet today was nothing new. It happens occasionally, but coincidentally it has happened each of the last 4 winters.

Average temperatures in the city have risen 6.5°F since 1909. Average # of freezing nights have dropped to 0.

Pasadena got a 14" of snow in 1949. https://t.co/r6JtMkt5ot

tweet:
In just 5 days, Los Angeles got:

- Scorching hot mid-winter heatwave up to 93°F
- Record warm Santa Ana wind
- Three small wildfires that burn at least 2 homes
- Sleet/hail in Pasadena, snow in Hesperia
- A rotating thunderstorm in Orange County, 
- THUNDERSNOW in Lake Arrowhead

I am not on day 934 of my daily trash pickups.

Thats why 934 days was so easy. I need these things, and I suspect some of you do too.

tweet:
This is why "global warming" is an incomplete, outdated term. Climate change does not just mean hotter.

It means the climate system we rely on is throwing us more curve-balls, and we're losing our ability to react.

The longer we wait to act, the more of us that have to pay. https://t.co/399MEUehD5

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
Temperatures are rising, which means rain is falling at elevations it should be snow, evaporation is increasing, and storms are producing heavier rainfall. 

Mid-winter heatwaves are catching people off guard, while a month prior 15-feet of snow was burying eastern CA cities. https://t.co/zhsAx9q0T6

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet: To sum up: Rainfall is not decreasing. It is becoming more erratic from year-to-year, and heavier from storm-to-storm. Impactful storms that drop more rain than we can handle are being following by 7-week dry spells that lead to wildfires in February. https://t.co/LNjrAu9yPh

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
In my area, April 2020-early December 2021 was THE driest 20-month period on record.

We got a single storm system of December 9th that dropped half an inch.

5 days later, a storm pummeled my canyon with 5" in a matter of hours, doing this to my park: https://t.co/QfvtVKg1P5

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
In winter 2018, the winter that had a record hot December (2017) and the most 80°F days on record, precipitation was below average.

What little that did fall fell in a matter of minutes, killing 20 people in Montecito. https://t.co/alI9gIYD3n https://t.co/oEZ55RpYGo

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet: A better indication of climate change in the L.A. Basin is 80°F winter days. In Pasadena, we averaged 5 such days per winter in the early 20th century. Today, we average 12. Winter 2014 and 2018 saw 24 such days! https://t.co/FnOwDTEnaN

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet: In terms of temperatures, the Los Angeles area no longer sees daytime highs below 50°F. MAYBE one occured in late November 2019 for some spots, but not in Pasadena. 90°F days are still not frequent, but they are happening more often. https://t.co/o8AYHKr43W

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet: What heavier, more erratic, more infrequent precipitation means for California is more flooding, more drought, more wildfires, more low-level fuel growth, more landslides, more storm erosion, and more headaches for the state.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
driest on record for much of the state. Mammoth Mountain recorded 161 inches of snowfall in December, their 3rd most ever for the month!!! 

In January, it did not snow. Period. The least ever for that month.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet: Contrary to popular belief, rainfall IS NOT decreasing. It is just falling in a shorter span of time. This winter is a perfect example of that. October 2021 and December 2021 are among the wettest months on record for this state. Meanwhile, November, January and February are THE

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
My park received 70-100 inches of rainfall between October 2004 and May 2005, our most ever. This is a Mediterranean climate, mind you.

In 2007, 8" fell throughout the whole water year. In 2021, just 7" fell. Those are the top-2 driest years ever.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
It is difficult to show this at a state level where local extremes get ironed out, but precipitation is becoming more variable. 

1998, 2005, and 2017 were the wettest years for much of the state.

2007, 2013, 2014, and 2021 were the driest years for much of the state.

Yikes. https://t.co/aLHB3RrJxk

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet: Winters are now far more variable than they used to be. Mid-winter dry spells, which were always a thing, have gotten longer and hotter. When storms do arrive, they come in sopping wet and dump huge amounts of precipitation.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet: Today, southern California is a radically different place. Winter rainstorms do not get going until November in most cases, January in the most extreme. Storms depart more quickly. It is, while still cloudy, usually dry by May.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet: The rainy season was more spread out back then. Temperatures began to really cool in October, and storms wouldn't fully depart until May. Again, winters were variable in precipitation totals.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet: An average winter in Los Angeles before climate change had average highs in the low-mid 60s, with a couple of 80°F days, and a dozens of days stuck in the 50s. A day stuck in the 40s occurred a few times a winter, while days over 90°F happened once a decade in winter. https://t.co/gQOv5FECyy

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
February is California's wettest month. We average 25% of annual rainfall during this time. Rainy seasons in California are naturally variable. Some years are wet while others are dry. This is normal.

Mountain snow feeds rivers and streams, while low-elevations see mostly rain. https://t.co/z8wVLSp7n9

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet: Southern California is a Mediterranean/semi-arid desert climate. 85% of the annual precipitation falls from November through April. May through October is predominately dry. 80% of Julys are rainless. This is completely normal, the ecology in this area is evolved for that. https://t.co/Syi7SZMW7J

name: Edgar McGregor

tweet:
To start your climate activism, you need to start smaller than you think you should.

Do something tiny. Watch a video on how CC impacts your region. Have a conversation with a fellow climate-weary friend.

Do something so little that you get that feeling that you could do more.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
Climate is about statistical probability.

There has been 33 years of climate change since April 1989. A heatwave of similar magnitude today but 6 days earlier... and March's old record gets a hit from a lineman.

I could honestly see 107°F.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
I'm really only half kidding.

Sometime in the next 20 years March should have a *killer* heatwave in SoCal. The current record is from 1916, one of our coldest years ever! It was 98°F in Pasadena.

April 5, 1989 reached 105°F, so I can easily see mid-100s in late March. https://t.co/dm373H4QlL https://t.co/N2FDJoOZfi

No level of extreme weather will get a politician to act on the climate crisis.

Not the leveling of a town by a wildfire, nor the breaching of a levee. Not the record obliterating heat, nor the disappearing ice.

It's up to us to stand up & say something. It's up to you and me.

tweet:
The color code is in increment of 5 degrees. The exception is yellow, which encompasses 64.4 to 69.9.

If all 12 month have an average temperature of 64.4F (18C), the climate is considered tropical. 

Only 4 months met this criteria in 1910. 

7 months, and soon an 8th, do today.

There were 5 days over 90°F between 1909 when records began and 1985. (76 years) 

There have been THIRTEEN 90°F February days in the 36 years since 1986. 5 of those days happened in 2016. Two more may occur this week-- we'll have to see.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
@Ble3ssedUnrest In the positive phase, SSTs over the decade are generally warmer than normal off the coast of CA. Of course, there are week-to week, and year-to-year variability, but it's influence is detectable.

We just flipped to a positive phase in ~2014. In 2015, March was our hottest ever.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
@Ble3ssedUnrest Nice eye.

There is a decades-long oscillation in SSTs in the North Pacific called the PDO.(Pacific Decadal Oscillation)

April and May are the two months where our temperature is most influenced by the Pacific Ocean ~20 miles away.

A & M temps *somewhat* correlate with the PDO. https://t.co/xwQWjk3zZv

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
One reason why I am studying climatology is that I really enjoy statistics.

In my area, the hottest MARCH on record, 2015, was hotter than any April on record.

It's a clear sign that within the next several years, the record for the hottest April ever will be obliterated. https://t.co/5lPoZlPLIK

January had a monthly record high of 79°F, a bit below average.  This statistic struggles to rise with climate change, at only +2.3°F over the 114 year period.

The month had a record minimum of 40°F. That statistic is catastrophically warming at +10.6°F over the 114 yr period. https://t.co/hcRa00moiw

description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
The month was 8.80°F above the early 20th century Januarys average. (climate change accounted)

The month was 1.27°F above the trendlines' expected value for 2022. (climate change ignored)

The month saw 23 days with a high temperature of 70°F or warmer, the 3rd most on record.

January 2022 data is in for Pasadena. 

The month came in 9th place for the hottest January on record with an average temperature of 59.9°F.

Average high of 71.7°F is the 14th hottest on record, while an average low of 48.2°F is the 11th hottest on record. https://t.co/ESsi7Ui6Tn

Tonight I am thinking of Big Santa Anita Canyon in Los Angeles. 

It was once the most lush part of southern California, with 40" of rainfall annually. 

In 2020 during a heat wave with high temperatures 110°F - 120°F, the whole place went up in flames.

Today, it is barren. https://t.co/uT4RuvHVua

If I had $10,000 to burn I'd work with the ANF to put several weather stations on these ridgelines. They may be even more exposed than the one I am standing on. 

Santa Ana winds that are cold in nature flow through canyons much like rivers do. Ridgelines get hit hardest.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
The ridgeline I am standing on contains a weather station that frequently records the top-5 strongest Santa Ana wind gusts in southern California.

I remember much cooler and cloudier days as a kid. I spend more time than ever outside. Marine layer fog used to sit around for days on end. 

Between June 2020 and June 2021, I saw the sun every single day. A year and 1 week. One day it rained 2" and the sun STILL came out.

tweet:
Well, I checked it. Crapola. What a rainy season for the record books. This is the 3rd anomaly in a row. 

2019-2020 had unusual wet-dry-wet flop (Mar and Apr wettest? wow!), 2020-2021 was our driest ever, and now 2021-2022 goes from massively wet to a total shutout. Incredible.

tweet:
The strongest wind I've ever stood in was 61.1 MPH during a trash pickup last January. I had to turn away from the wind, hold my breath, slam my eyes shut, and dig my feet into the ground. I almost fell over again. 

I can't imagine 100 MPH.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
I think people vastly overestimate the winds they've experienced. I just stood in a 47 MPH gust. I know because I had an anemometer in my hand. 

That this was p.o.w.e.r.f.u.l. 

It nearly knocked me off my feet, blew sand into my eyes, and made the trees go sideways.

tweet:
Individual action is not enough to stop climate breakdown without system change. 

What they don’t tell you is that system change is not enough to stop climate breakdown without individual action.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
The solution to the climate crisis is not for someone to develop a miracle technology.

The solution is not for a heroic leader to emerge from the clouds to save us from ourselves. 

No, the solution is for you, and me, and everyone we know to stand up and say something.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:

We need you loud. The planet needs you loud. The future needs you loud.

We need more climate activists.

tweet:
Satellite imagery shows that the carving out of this new tributary happened in the 2005 flash flood. When the river is flowing heavily, both sides flow. However, when the stream begins to dry, only the blue side flows.

I moved that rock today to help the pink side flow too. https://t.co/o1E4wJLPed

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
There is a part of my park where the stream, upon placing a single rock, can split for 1/5th of a mile. 

Simply placing that rock gives way to this new tributary which helps bring water to native plants and trees far from the river.

Here is that little tributary. https://t.co/9RP7Kni46F

@zjmaayan @Spencer_Berg_ Science on tectonic plates is barely a half century old. We have limited ability to collect data on BOTH of the fields the author is trying to connect.

This is frontier climate science. It may be true! But I am skeptical of whether our current technology can determine the truth.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
Tsunamis are not being affected by climate change directly. They are not caused by climate change, nor are they made stronger or more frequent by climate change.

They are only indirectly affected in the form of sea level rise assisting in land inundation.

The potential for a record-annihilating hot summer (JJA) in southern California is high.

Flattening out the trendline on summer temps, we can see that summers have been as hot a 4°F above average in the past.

The hottest summer on record, 2006, was only 2.8°F above average!! https://t.co/NIEXmE2kLV

There is WAY MORE climate science on the frontier than there is in the core. (core meaning stuff everyone in the community agrees on)

Tread carefully when coming across articles that appear to be on the frontier. It may not be rock solid.

tweet:
Being my autistic self tonight and pouring over climate data again.

I wanted to know the hottest 31-day period in my city's history. Turns out it was the 31 days between September 4th and October 5th, 2020.

OCTOBER.

The average high was 97.9°F. Unreal for coastal California. https://t.co/vD9BZeCnrf

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
A quick look at January average high temperatures over the past 114 years for Pasadena, CA:

In the early 1900s our average high in Jan was ~64°F.

Today, it is 69.4°F.    (+5.4°F)

The first January with an average high of 80°F is 10-20 years out. February reached that in 2016. https://t.co/5Xj6veqKCP https://t.co/X5ZvoeQzPX

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
This trendline is suspiciously slow. November and December are similar, but N + D are the 2 slowest warming months with climate change!

April is the 4th FASTEST warming month, March is 5th, and May is 7th!

Big changes are coming to the y-axis on this graph in the coming years. https://t.co/aT99N2DzG8

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
The past 10 years has been full of summer, fall, and winter heatwaves. 115°F in July 2018, 120°F in September 2020, 106°F in late October 2017, 95°F on Thanksgiving 2017, 90°F in January 2021.

But those Spring months. Man... one of these years we're going to get hit hard.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet: Springtime heat waves hit fast and furious. The public may be unprepared, the power grid may not be able to handle the increased A/C use, and those without basic protection from the elements (ie homeless) will be put at significantly higher risk than from summer heatwaves.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
Yes, it is pure speculation. But do not underestimate climate change. I remember myself laughing at the GFS for predicting 120°F in Canada. 

March and May's monthly maximums are particularly vulnerable to being blown out of the water by 6°F - 10°F, and this is a problem.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
Because of 1989's 105°F in early April, those 106 years of warming, and the fact that the current March monthly maximum occurred on the 10th...

I see no reason why a high temperature of 108°F isn't possible in the final 2 weeks of March sometime in the next 50 years.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
1916 was Pasadena's COLDEST YEAR EVER! There has been 106 years of climate change and 106 years of urban heat island growth since then!

It's not that heatwaves in this month are cooler. It is that every time we roll the dice, we escape a March heat wave. Our luck WILL run out. https://t.co/iskLJDV1Yz

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
I really believe temperatures pushing 110°F during the months of APRIL AND MAY in coastal southern California is already possible.

Now, March. March is even more frightening. March's monthly record maximum region-wide is in the upper 90s. For Pasadena, that was March 10th, 1916.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
1. April's monthly record high is higher than May's because of that event. Already, May's numbers are very easily beatable.

2. That event happened ON APRIL 6TH! So even April's numbers can be beaten.

3. There has been 33 years of climate change and urban heat island growth.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
The keystone event was April 6, 1989 when temperatures exceeded 105°F region-wide.

Okay, first of all, 105°F in early April is messed up. That event had the highest standard deviation, but I want to mention three things:

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
Here is a list of the top 5 most anomalous spring heatwaves for our area:

1. April 1989, widespread mid-100s
2. March 1916, widespread upper 90s.
3. May 1910, widespread lower 100s. 
4. May 1927, widespread lower-mid 100s.
5. May 2014, widespread mid-100s.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
Yes, the trendline in those graphs is moving, but the hottest of heatwaves aren't warming all that much. 

I think this is a massive illusion. From what we saw last summer in the PNW, I think a major southern California springtime heatwave has not struck since April 1989.

tweet:
For someone on day 900 of clearing trash, I really don't mind the littering of glass in bodies of water. 

Glass is made from sand, is non-toxic, and unless sharp, it has no affect on water ecosystems.

On land, its no good, but we really should switch back to glass from plastic. https://t.co/AgvrV5lmh1

It is making them deadlier, more destructive, and more costly.

name: Edgar McGregor

At 1-hour a day for 886 days and for $15 an hour, my daily trash pickups would have earned me $13,290 before taxes.

I cleaned up L.A.'s 3rd most popular park with a bucket and a pair of gloves.

LAPD drains that kind of cash every 2 minutes and 19 seconds. "No funding" my ass.

tweet:
Part of why the urban forest is stopping these temperatures from reaching higher levels isn't the shade that is generated, but the humidity. December heat waves must be very dry as the sun isn't strong enough to heat up a saturated atmosphere.

Our gardens moisten the atmosphere. https://t.co/Cw5bnqSIX6

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
2021 reached 88°F on the 1st, the warmest December high since 1979. That was coming off our hottest November ever. This trend may reverse with climate change if it hasn't already. 

December's all-time maximum of 93°F in 1958 is safe... for now.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
Of the hundreds of temperatures statistics I have analyzed in my city over the years, this is the only one where temperatures are actually dropping.

Due to a low sun angle and the new urban forest, the hottest of December days can no longer get as hot as they did long ago. https://t.co/kl69KGahSx

tweet:
Of the 46 days we've added to the annual mean (remember December took away 1), three months are responsible for HALF of this change in annual count. 

April (+7.5 days), May (+6.9 days), and October (+8.1 days). The other half is shared among the remaining 7 months. https://t.co/C4XjTGghPp

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
This urban forest is offsetting the effects of climate change for this particular stat.

Take note at November's lack of years with <5 80°F days since 2004. Every year is now closer to the mean, something you might expect when water (high heat content) is put into the equation.

name: Edgar McGregor

tweet:
How have the number of 80F days in Nov and Dec changed? They haven't!🤯

Why?

Well, hot weather in these months is closely tied to dry air in SoCal. Up until the 1930s, Pasadena was farmland with few established trees. Now, the big, dense (wet) urban forest may prevent 80F days. https://t.co/AIAqIXb3sD

tweet:
Big change in the annual number of 80°F days over the past century plus for my area of Los Angeles.

Numbers are quite literally off the charts. 100 years ago, we averaged 135 such days per year.

Today, we average 180 days (+45). Climate change & urban heat islands are to blame. https://t.co/vX7tTiNkWC

Geologists don't debate whether rocks exist.
Psychologists don't debate whether the brain exists.

So why do people still expect climate scientists to debate whether climate change exists? The science is in.

The debate we need to be having is how we're going to solve this.

We hit 111 (44°F) for the first time ever in 2010. 
We hit 113°F (45°C) for the first time ever in 2018
We hit 116°F (47°C) for the first time ever in 2020. 
Records go back to 1893. 

I was told it was "normal" by a classmate.

2012, 2015, and 2020 each saw two consecutive months that were their hottest on record (Sept 2012 and 2020 are tied for 1st)

Two all-time record hot months in a row... 3 times in one decade?!? Thats climate breakdown. https://t.co/ngu0Ivfa5S

tweet: I have found mice and other small rodents that squeeze their way into glass bottles to drink liquid inside. Unfortunately, they can't get back out and eventually die. While some glass bottles are homes, others are traps. This is part of how my cleanups save my park's wildlife.

name: Edgar McGregor

tweet:
The other day a lizard leapt out of my bucket and scared the crap out of me. He was inside a glass bottle I had picked up.

I didn't know which one, but I checked what I had and didn't see anything else inside these bottles.

This lizard was lucky to get out...(1/2) TW: death https://t.co/w5vJYyrREq

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
We didn't have a winter last year in California.

In my part of L.A.:

- It was 94°F on January 15th.
- The average high for the entire winter was 74°F
- Barely 6" of rain fell, an all time record low.

Climate change kicked our ass last year. These storms mean everything. https://t.co/QH57hjGy5O

tweet:
This is striking:

The 2021 Southwest Monsoon season was commendable, with many locations seeing a top-5 wettest monsoon.

But that doesn't matter for our water storage along the Colorado River.

What we need is snowfall in Utah and Colorado. Climate change threatens that. https://t.co/WlCbgyXD0V

The big totals are from a storm 7-10 days out, and the 18z GFS, 0z GFS, and 0z EURO are all agreeing. It's far out, but not 16 days.

tweet:
A ~6 year old new weather station near my home park in L.A. has just recorded it's warmest November so far, with an average high of 82°F!

This is the 7th month of the year to have an average high over 80°F.

It has been almost 2 years since a month had an average high below 70°F https://t.co/hloTxqeXJt

tweet:
2021 just exacturbated that trend.

November and December are the slowest warming months with climate change in this part of southern California. 

That can't continue forever. Their warming must eventually accelerate. 

For November, that may already be happening. Average temps: https://t.co/AtTxcLpmdV

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
In terms of average high temperature, November 2021 was the 2nd hottest November on record for Pasadena, CA behind only 1949.

Our average high was 81.5°F (27.5°C) for the month!

There has been a total shutdown in year-to-year variability in this statistic since about 2010. https://t.co/aH7x08soHD

tweet:
In these maps alone, we had about 

- 200 stations operable during October 15th, 2018's wind event

- 500 stations operable in February 4th, 2020's event

- **1,000** weather stations operable during November 25, 2021's event.

Incredible.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
The Santa Ana winds were named as such in 1882, and have been known by indigenous peoples for 5,000 yrs.

However, it wasn't until 2019 that we had enough weather stations to sufficiently measure these wind events.

Look at the change in # of stations between 2018, 2020, & 2021! https://t.co/5XOiT9S5pN

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
@RubbleStarky Too bad we didn't' have much windstorm data from back then. In fact, it wasn't until the 2019-2020 windstorm season that we had enough weather stations across L.A. to accurately measure a wind event.

A comparison of the weather station count between 2018, 2019, and 2021: https://t.co/mmdjFdZ6fa

Class 3: Power flashes, 1s trees down
Class 4: 10s trees down, cars damaged
Class 5: Cars smashed, a few homes damaged/destroyed, windows blown out, 100s trees down

The important thing to remember with many of these graphs is that I am only showing you PAST warming in my city.

What you see is what has already happened. If I add the next 79 years... what could 2100 bring?

Our choices matter.
Are we ready?
Or are we still stuck on coal? https://t.co/0hOUSaLyCd

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
Yep, and there it is. We just reached 90°F.

Today, November 14th, is the ONE HUNDREDTH 90°F+ day of summer 2021 in my city, Pasadena, CA.

There has been a dangerous rise in the number of 90°F+ days annually.

Only 2017 saw more days at 102 instances. That record will not last. https://t.co/bMkVBCoqh3 https://t.co/hyLY62ZlMj

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
Thank you for liking my graphs. I really enjoy making them, and although they are only specific for my area, I like sharing them with the world.

Every place on Earth experiences climate change differently. It is important for climatologist to know what these diverse changes are.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
In December, the warmest years are not getting any warmer. Instead, all of the warming has come from a total disappearance in cold Decembers.

Essentially, every December has been "above average" since the 1990s without the hottest Decembers getting warmer.

That may change soon.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
Five years ago when I first made this graph, I had already noticed November and December were not warming with climate change nearly as much as the other months.

This is changing with November, but something different is happening with December (1/2). https://t.co/32RwXZnrst https://t.co/e0g6CmMqRw

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
Hot weather this week and favored above average temperatures over the next two weeks means 2021 will  be no exception.

There is a clustering in average temperatures in November at the top of the range, suggesting the range itself has jumped upwards over the last ~20 years. https://t.co/n5iaJqnqWV

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
November and December are the slowest warming months with climate change in southern California, especially when it comes to average highs.

That may be about to change.... if not already.

In the last 10 years, year-to-year variability in November average highs has collapsed. https://t.co/kbVer11bn0

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
With today's 93°F high, summer 2021 now stands at a total of 99 days >/=90°F in Pasadena, CA.

This is the 2nd highest number of 90°F+ days in a single summer since records began in 1908.

Top 5:

2017: 102 days
*2021: 99
2016: 98
1990: 98
2020: 97
2014: 97
2015: 87
1996: 87 https://t.co/TZ6eQL69Tq

tweet:
There has been a steady increase in recent years in high temperatures over 90°F in my part of Los Angeles. 

In the early 20th century, we averaged 41 such days per year. Today, we average 76!

5 of the last 8 years saw nearly 100 such days, an incredible feat.

2021 saw 96 days. https://t.co/F7bYJMseO0

Highs pushing 95°F will be common in L.A. this Friday.

The monthly record high each November has risen 2.1°F since 1908 in Pasadena, a relatively slow place.

In the last decade, however, all but 1 year has seen the monthly high fall above the trendline. Warming is accelerating. https://t.co/dHqzBtpmTn https://t.co/y25djGWBkV

tweet:
What you are looking at is ridges of high pressure (warm, sunny weather) continuously building off the west coast over the next 15 days keeping CA dry.

This pattern, called "Ridiculously Resilient Ridge," is to blame for CA's drought.

We do NOT want to see this in Dec-Feb. https://t.co/lrQZRhdP8J

tweet:
2020 is virtually tied with 2014 for the warmest autumn on record. 

I have been alive for all but three of the top 10 hottest Octobers on record, and my existence accounts for 18% of the record book.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
Autumn is rapidly warming in my area (Pasadena, CA) with temps rising +7.3°F (4.1°C) since records began in 1908.

September and October are the 1st and 2nd fastest warming months, while amazingly, November is the 2nd slowest.

Autumn 2021 should come in just below the trendline. https://t.co/e0TnS8OKMq

The average temp in October has warmed 8.27°F over the last 114 years, since 1908. October is the second fastest warming month of the year, behind September.

The monthly low of 48°F fell below the trendline.

1.33" of rain fell in October, making it the wettest Oct since 2011. https://t.co/m2BOff0DO3

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
The average temp in Oct 2021 in Pasadena, CA fell 1.86°F below the trendline, but 6.37°F above the early 20th century avg temp for October.

2021 is still the 4th warmest year on record to date, behind 2012, 2015, and 2014.

The monthly high was 98°F, which fell on the trendline. https://t.co/jHsZaGb7tu

tweet: Notice how the first image in this tweet nearly matches the first image in the retweet. That is because in the early 20th century, the effects of CC were negligible. So, you would expect the two graphics to look similar. As climate change tightens its grip, the numbers separate.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
Now, how can I look at temperature anomalies without climate change interfering with the data?

First, I have to give every single month of every single year it's own unique trendline-based average temp. Then, just use subtraction to remove the effects of CC on the data.

tweet:
@itsarigrace Hurricanes are essential. They serve to balance the differences in atmosphere between the tropics and the polar regions.

When a hurricane moves poleward and dies, it injects colossal amounts of moisture and heat into the higher latitudes. Without Hs, the poles would far cooler.

Have it every now and again, it will taste so much better, and it really lets you appreciate the life that was given.

tweet:
In 1957, the avg. October temperature was +5.2°F from the trend-based average for that year, the record highet departure for this month.

In 2020, October was +4.7°F from the trend-based average for that year. BUT, in terms of actual average temps, 2020 puts 1957 to shame.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
One year ago today, we ended the hottest October week ever recorded in my area. The *average* daily high temp for the first 8 days of Oct. 2020 was 100°F!!

The year, it is cooler... thank God.

But the trend is upwards. There WILL be a hotter October. This is the climate crisis. https://t.co/2fwVikPxNL https://t.co/UDhrmOedCQ

7% of the entire state has been torched in a wildfire in the last 18 months.

If this next rain season doesn't happen... what the hell are we going to do?

tweet:
Fun fact: That 98F from March still stands as the March monthly record high.

On April 5th and 6th 1989, temperatures reached 105°F. With 30+ years of climate change and UHI since, if a repeat of that heat wave occurs 1 week earlier, that 98F record high gets annihilated by 10F.

@alienghic On January 22, 1943, 26" fell at Camp Hogee's.

Based on Ponderosa Pinetree log locations, the river in my park saw a peak flow of roughly 200ft wide, and 3-20ft (avg 6) deep. At a speed of 3m/s, (it's a mountain wash), it had a discharge of ~10,000 cubic feet of water / second.

tweet:
Excuse me, that is 103 days over 90°F, not 95°F.

We are at 62 days over 95°F so far this summer, outpacing 2020's 57 days as of October 3rd. 2020 finished at an all-time record high with 66 days. We need 5 more to beat 2020 and secure the title. No 95°F days in the forecast.

tweet:
Every region shaded in brown just saw their driest water year ever recorded.

They are: Ventura and Los Angeles Counties, the southern Sierra Nevada, an ENORMOUS swath of northern California, parts of the Great Basin, part of northern Utah, and parts of southern Oregon and Idaho. https://t.co/GgLZQwHjNg

tweet:
Most of Ventura County, as well as the Los Angeles County Mountains through Pasadena, have just experienced our driest water year ever recorded. 

The water years ends on September 30, begins Oct. 1 as to not split up the rainy season.

Truly a remarkable drought hitting CA. https://t.co/29VCjCOP9O

tweet: The latest 100°F on record was 101°F on November 4, 2010. Given that we've had 11 years of climate change since, and in 2017 it was 107°F on the 24th of October, I'm willing to guess to last possible day to see 100°F is November 15th. After that, it's meteorologically impossible.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
I am hoping today's 100°F high will be the last of 2021 for my area.

Overall, summer 2021 went better than most years. We had no huge heatwaves (>104°F, 40°C) until September, and then we got 2.

However, the number of >95°F days is outpacing even last year, at 103 days so far. https://t.co/Dn7PccbldD

@AlaskaWx They are actually majority Southern California Edison (SCE) weather stations that they implemented after Paradise, CA burned down.

These are completely different from PWS weather stations, are usually on SCE power poles, and are used to prevent wildfires. https://t.co/tZ0i3JuneM https://t.co/ZGT82w5yeJ

tweet:
Mount Wilson holds the western United States record for the most rainfall in 24 hours: 25 inches on Jan 22, 1943.

Our south-southwest facing coast slopes rise up 6,000 feet  on the front range. This height, steepness, proximity to the ocean, and low latitude are all responsible.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
2005 was our wettest rain year, with a whopping 56 inches of rain! My canyon picked up 70-90 inches during that time due to orographic lift. 

Just two years later, 2007 was our driest year ever until this morning when the 2021 water year ended.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
With 6.05" inches of rainfall, the 2020-2021 water year in my city, Pasadena, California, is officially the driest in 113 years since records began.

This beats 2006-07's record of 6.24".

Average rainfall is on a downward trend, though year-to-year variability is very high. https://t.co/2Cj4bMPyoX

The water year ends on September 30 and begins on October 1 out here.

In the west, the rainy season begins in October. Since we don't want to split up a single season and put two halves of different seasons together, we use water years.

tweet:
It irks me how much cities refuse to clean up trash in their parks and on their beaches and highways. It is such an easy thing to fix. You've just got to put money forward and hire people.

If you've got a trash problem in your city, it's not the litterbugs. It's policy failure.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
Diversity is the key to our success. The more people we have fighting the climate crisis, the more WAYS people are fighting the CC, and the more likely we'll succeed.

So become a climate activist in any which way you can.  But tweeting "______ activists should..." isn't helpful.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
All ways of being a climate activist are valid ways. It is impossible to be a "perfect" climate activist. There is no such thing. That is why we live by the motto "do what you can, when you can."

As a matter of fact, it is A GOOD THING that we aren't all the same.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet: For some, fighting the climate crisis means getting rid of cars and riding a bike. For others, it means eating less meat. And for some, it means standing in the way of politicians who are trying to sell out our future.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
Picking up litter does NOT make me a better climate activist than others. It is simply my way of being a climate activist.

Everyone has their own specific ways of being a climate activist. It's all about your own personal ability to act.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet: Litter is unsightly, it can kills animals, and it can pollute water and soil. It also is SUCH AN EASY problem to fix! The two keys to success is human power and consistency. Hire people, hire enough people, and have them keep coming back to make sure an area STAYS clean.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
Litter picking is fun. I love it, it gives me time to be in nature, and it gives me time to think about the climate crisis and what we should do about it.

It is an important issue. Our natural world is already facing the climate crisis. We don't need to face municipal waste too.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
This particular issue has the potential to dangerously alter the trajectory of human civilization. If it goes unaddressed, the climate crisis will be the last chapter in our book.

This isn't to say other problems aren't bad, it's just that this is the worst one.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
The climate crisis has the potential to completely alter the story of life on planet Earth. It will be a pronounced change in the geological record forever, and it could take 10,000,000 years for Earth to recover *as of today*.

No other environmental problem is that bad.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
Hello. I'm a climate activist. I pick up trash every single day. Let's talk.

On our little planet here, we face a number of environmental issues. Water pollution, municipal waste, habitat loss, and overfishing are to name a few.

None of those compare to the climate crisis.

tweet:
This is a result of the loss of the town of Paradise, CA and 85 of its residents in 2018. Local energy companies are installing these stations to (controversially) shut off power in areas experiencing fire weather.

My community had 6 stations in Sept. 2017. 
Today, we have 43.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
Did you know Los Angeles has the highest concentration of weather stations in the world?

The NYC region has about 300 or so weather stations compared to SoCal's 2,000+ weather stations. 

Weather stations are essential in wildland-urban interfaces to track wildfire conditions. https://t.co/oIxYQtdUW0

tweet:
Doing what you can, when you can to help preserve the planet, no matter how much that may actually be, makes you a climate activist.

Thank you. You're a hero.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
I didn't make Eaton Canyon southern California's cleanest park through a mythical level of motivation and heroism.

I just took a hike there every day with a bucket and did what I could, when I could.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
Honestly, I have failed in relaying the messages that my trash pickups are not some huge project I work on that takes a special mindset to replicate.

They are just daily strolls in the park, folks. Anyone can do them. They are not costly in terms of time or energy (usually.)

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
Why is it contagious? Because doing what you can, when you can isn't that hard. If you can't do something, that is okay. It's not your fault.

Climate activism that centers doing what you can when you can makes helping t0 save the world sound so much easier... less like a chore.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
2 people doing what they can, when they can is a contagious act.

2 becomes 4. 4 becomes 7. 7 becomes 17. 17 becomes 29. 29 becomes 63. 63 becomes 198. 198 becomes 456 people doing what they can, when they can.

 The other is not contagious.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
1 perfect climate activist is nothing compared to just 2 people just doing what they can, when they can to help the planet. 

We do not need perfect climate activists. We need MORE climate activists. Only then can we make real change.

Gosh... these cleanups are so short.

They'll get longer eventually. https://t.co/4U6QZP7ECs

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
This also means that I obviously cannot update my summer graphics until November.

September is starting out hotter than any point this summer, but not like last year. (116F on the 5th) The rest of the month and October are not currently forecasted to be exceptionally hot.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
So, what is the solution? I cannot assign just 3 months to my summer graphics.

In some years, June and July are brutal. In other years, October puts July to shame like last year.

Our summers are 5 months long, so this is the only fair graphic: 2014 wins, followed by 2020. https://t.co/3mYnxxPfxH

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
Now, when kicking out July and adding October, summer 2020 clearly stands out as the most brutal summer ever. A summer so extreme should not be meteorologically possible in this part of the world.

Important: October 2020 was hotter than July 2020, so I am allowed to do this. https://t.co/Y3qCqWUv7f

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
Summer 2020 was arguably worse, however. Summer here is defined as June, July, and August. In coastal southern California, September is FAR hotter than June. 

When dropped June and adding September, the years of 2012, 2014, and 2020 are now in the lead. https://t.co/fItyznwL0z

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
Summer 2021 (June/July/Aug) has just virtually tied with 2006 for the hottest summer on record in 114 years of weather record keeping in my city, Pasadena, CA.

Like 2006, there were no extreme heatwaves this year. A warm summer instead comes from a lack of below average days. https://t.co/3k0PoifVjN

tweet:
October is warming at about 1 degree every 12 years, and that rate is accelerating. 

Only September is faster, at a current rate of 1 degree every 11 years.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet: @offroadartist June was bad, but August was nothing compared to last year. Heat arrived early, but never became exceptional. So we have a record high 90F and 95F days, but one of the lowest number of 100F days in recent years.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
I say "I doubt that will happen again," I mean this year and this year alone.

October 2008, 2014, and 2015 were exceptional. 2020 crushed the competition. This month is experiencing a radical shift in climate, dangerously lengthening our summer.

There WILL be a hotter October. https://t.co/3L4L31aTGt

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
Will we top 2020? October had 2 days over 105°F, 9 days over 100°F, and 17 days over 90°F. Absolutely blew the previous hottest October out of the water. I doubt that'll happen again.

Nevertheless, this has been a tough summer. Relentless heat... but few exceptionally hot days. https://t.co/3qg8VVyX9L

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
Last year we recorded 126 days with a high temperature of 90°F or greater in my part of L.A. It is our most 90°F days in a single year ever recorded.

As of Sept. 11th of last year, we were at 86 days over 90°F so far.

We're at 91 days so far this year, 5 above the record pace.

tweet:
Pasadena, California needs 0.19" of rainfall in the next 20 days to avoid having the driest water year ever recorded in 114 years of record keeping.

The current record is 6.24" during the 2006-2007 water year. As of now, 2021 sits as 6.05". A strong cell just passed to our east. https://t.co/vnah20yYDb

tweet:
Since SST's do not change easily, they can make a given year consistently warm or cool.

Southern California was plagued in 2014 and 2015 by very warm sea surface temperatures that kept overnight lows high. It is responsible for the year being so warm. https://t.co/52DGfFgvQ4

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet: My thought process leads to ocean temperatures, which do not change very easily. Perhaps the Pacific Ocean's SST's near the coast now play a much bigger role in whether we have a hot year or cold year than before.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
2014 is not only our hottest year ever, but it's the year furthest above the trendline than any other. 2019 is the same, but further BELOW the trendline than any other.

One would need to consider whether anomalous weather was increasing in duration & constancy through the year.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
2014 and 2019.

Both years were very suddenly near or over 3°F from the trend based average, and are the #1 and #3 most anomalous years on record. That is not nothing. What the heck happened?

1 PM massive chills in bed
3 PM excessively hot, warmer than before
5 PM fine
7 PM better.
9 PM normal

Nothing after that. No idea wtf happened.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
September 2020:

The smoke following that massive heatwave was unfathomable. AQI over 600 for days on end. It was so bad, we could not go outside without coughing. 

No overnight relief, but even if there was, the smoke was worse at night. No A/C? Yikes. https://t.co/aSDefIe12k

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
September 6, 2020.

Our second ever heatwave to top 120°F west of the mountains. This time, several stations met the threshold. It was clear on this day a new era of heat waves were beginning. 

Some spots saw a low temperature of 100°F. Put October, 24, 2017 to shame. https://t.co/uSjh2GfEuY

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
January 17, 2019

Days of heavy rain totally 5 inches sent flash flooding down my park. This flooding was nothing compared to the January 2005 flood in which 10 inches of rain fell over 3 days. 

Neither flood compares to Jan 22, 1943... 26 inches fell in my park in 24 hours. https://t.co/N9ZVRe35ug

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
July 6, 2018.

Our first ever heatwave to top 120°F in coastal southern California. This heatwave only forced a few stations above that threshold. These stations could have over recorded the temperatures, but plenty of other stations were in the upper 110s.

The forecast: https://t.co/cXDbJI9Dgu

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
October 24, 2017.

Another windstorm hit. This one brought heat instead of high winds.

Temperatures remained between 85°F and 95°F between 2 AM and 6 AM that morning. Highs 105°F+. They were the perfect conditions for an enormous firestorm.

We were spared. Santa Rosa was not. https://t.co/4r7UcpdQ5J

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
These winds were powerful enough to pull up sidewalks, snap concrete traffic lights like twigs, and knock out power to everyone for days or even weeks. 

There were no deaths, but a few close calls. Some people did lose their homes. https://t.co/EuYgKDM1ke

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
November 30, 2011.

I was 11. Santa Ana windstorms were common in winter here, but nobody knew what was about to occur that night. There was very little warning.

Between 9 PM and midnight that night, a Santa Ana windstorm blasted my area with winds in excess of 100 MPH. https://t.co/x9dik4Rf5J

tweet:
@Niyologist @StuOstro When a hurricane decides it doesn't want it's inner eyewall, it cuts off moisture to it and ends thunderstorm development. An outer eyewall forms, expanding the wind field, but lowering the maximum wind.

The net result is a worse human impact since more will see an eyewall.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
In the future, once we collect more data, we will be able to observe a change in the total number of tropical cyclones IF there is one. 

For now, focus on how a hurricane in 2017 sat over Texas for 5 days and dumped 60 inches of rainfall. Climate change helped make that happen.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
However, this does not mean tropical entities are not being affected by climate change.

We have observed that tropical entities are rapidly intensifying more quickly AND more frequently, these storms are moving slower upon landfall, and they are dumping heavier rainfall.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet: In addition, the exact definition of a tropical cyclone isn't a fine line. Our techniques to determine their tropical characteristics have only recently become satisfactory. Even today, storms can receive a name that some in the Wx science community think shouldn't have been.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
While this graph does show an "increase," note the dates.

It has only been since the 1980s that we can say with accuracy how many tropical cyclones the North Atlantic basin sees each year. We have very likely been missing storms that never make landfall in the century prior. https://t.co/xGJr3V77cK

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
I want to quickly remind everyone that while the intensity, flood potential, and speed of tropical cyclones is being affected by climate change, the total number of them is not.

We have not observed an increase in the total number of tropical cyclones per year on Earth.

In terms of trend based averages, 2019 was far and away the most anomalously cool year we've ever experienced at a whopping 2.75°F below average. 2014 was the warmest.

Every year between 1909 (when records began) and 1957 was colder.

February was the coldest Feb since 1956!! https://t.co/EOiR7spvjt

tweet:
July 2021 was the 3rd hottest July on record for my city, which has record that spans 114 years. 

April and June were their 6th hottest on record.
This is our driest year on record.

Oh, and January mached it's monthly record high with 94°F (34°C) on the 15th.

Climate change! https://t.co/L1XtokfbdY

tweet:
Clear the brush now. Get the pine needles off your roof now. Make an evacuation plan now. 

Because again, even if this particular fire gets nowhere near close, a new one can start up at any time near you and move in quickly. You want to be prepared for anything.
