description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet: During that 24 hour period, my city recorded 14 inches of rainfall, which actually checks out. The mountains receive significantly more rain than the valley due to orographic lift.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet: I did a rather crude study on the Ponderosa Pine logs deposited by this flash flood, 1938's flash flood, 1969's flash flood, and 2005's. It's a rough estimate, but about 5,000 cubic feet of water needed to be coming out of the canyon per second to deposit the logs where they are. https://t.co/i3e1bjZBgT

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
Did you know that my park holds the western United States record for most rainfall in a 24-hour period?

25 inches of rain... more than TWO FEET... fell between 1 AM on January 22 and 1 AM on January 23, 1943.

My park was underwater, needless to say. 
https://t.co/pw5wJlH8rg https://t.co/4u9cXfOaVI

tweet:
I'm aware it says 1960-1961 as the driest year. There are 5 days missing from the 2006-2007 record, all in December 2006. If a single month has 5 or more missing days, the whole year is tossed.

Those 5 days were dry according to other nearby stations, so I'm trusting the record. https://t.co/6dXsnN8kZc

tweet:
As it currently stands, my hometown in southern California is on track to have our driest water year on record, with rainfall records going back to the year 1908.

Only 6.04" of rain has fallen since October 1, 2020. The current record is 6.24" in the parched 2006/07 water year. https://t.co/MX0VbpBvei https://t.co/jLmFxWsOgq

tweet:
Seven years ago this month, the historic 2010s California drought peaked.

58% of the state was covered by exceptional drought, and 81% by extreme. 

Today, drought has returned with 49% of the state under exceptional conditions, but 88% under extreme.

The forecast looks dry. https://t.co/pQV3RRy39u

tweet:
The best solution: Let indigenous communities conduct burns during the offseason to help clear forest underbrush.

This prepares the forests for the dry season and prevents megafires.

Their cultures have been doing this for thousands of years. They know what they are doing.

name: Edgar McGregor

tweet:
Wildfires are getting worse in CA for 3 reasons:

1. Decades of fire suppression has allowed fuels to build in our forests.

2. Climate change is providing these fires with heat, dead trees, and dry soils.

3. More homes have built up in the forests in the paths of these fires. https://t.co/VqovSHuHJb

This is desertification being viewed live.

Systematic climate action cannot be successful without individual climate action. 

The two are not mutually exclusive. They are not two. They are one.

We ALL need to act. Everywhere.

tweet:
Climate activism isn't just about annihilating the fossil fuel industry. 

It is about showing others our place in this Universe. It is about proving to ourselves what we're capable of. It is about leaving a better world for the future so they can do the same.

That's who we are.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
We have the opportunity to build a completely sustainable civilization. One where time no longer works against us.

Ask yourself: Wouldn't you want to live in a world you'd be proud to show your kids?

With your help, that becomes a reality. 

Become a climate activist.
Please.

tweet:
Since 1909, the driest 483-day period (which is the length of our current dry stretch (mid-April 2020 to present) ) is June 2006 - September 2007 at 4.3" of rain over that ~16 month period.

We're currently sitting at 5.88" since 4/2020. We're in second place. 2013-14 is in 3rd.

@RWare7 March and June are heavily influenced by onshore flow, and so the ocean moderates Los Angeles's temperature. During September and October, there is neither onhore nor offshore flow in this part of L.A. (typically)

So the urban heat island is more often stuck in place in S and O.

The fastest warming nights are in September, where we're warming at a rate of +1°F every 10 years.

We're at +11.2°F of warming over the last 114 years, which is astounding. https://t.co/u1RcqORcFJ

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
Overnight relief in my city during August, our hottest month, is becoming increasingly difficult to come by.

Overnight lows during the month are warming at a rate of +1°F every 12 years.

We're at +9.7°F over the last 114 years.

Climate change, along with the UHI, is to blame. https://t.co/lZTpzCue3R

tweet:
@19katekat52 Pasadena's record highest temperature in the summer of 1971 was 108°F on September 12. 

Between when records began in 1909 and 2009, Pasadena never saw a temperature warmer than 110°F.

In 2010, we reached 111°F.
In 2018, we reached 113°F.
And in 2020, we reached 116°F.

tweet:
What is a weather event you've seen in the last year that was likely made worse by the climate crisis?

On September 6, 2020, L.A. was smashing all time record high temperatures. We reached 116°F. Even worse, our overnight lows were scorching.

It was 102°F on my *predawn* hike!

tweet:
Three reasons why wildfires are getting worse:

- Increased wildland-urban interfaces; we're building more homes in forests.

- Decades of fire supression has allowed fuels to build up across the western U.S.

- The climate crisis is increasing drought and temps, helping fires.

Only 2018's #MendocinoComplex and 2020's #AugustComplex are bigger. 

All 7 of the top 7 largest wildfires on record have occurred in the last 3 years.

Records go back to 1932. https://t.co/8tBOLqt7Rb

description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
@ryanhaaswx @Climatologist49 @AlaskaWx It all has to do with dry air. In September/Oct/Nov, the onshore flow stops. Cool Pacific can't help us anymore, and dry descending air from the Great Basin heats up fast.

In winter, sun angle means everything. The instant the solstice passes, we slowly begin to warm.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
@ryanhaaswx @Climatologist49 @AlaskaWx Yep. Our average warmest day is August 23th, followed by our average coolest 4 months later on December 27th. 

But temperatures hardly drop in September, and that is usually when our hottest heat waves are. Avg temps are slowly rising for 8/9 months, and then plummet for 3/4.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
@AlaskaWx @Climatologist49 Coastal CA does that for you. All of the major heat waves that have hit the western U.S. this year have been no match for the onshore flow off the cold Pacific.

In Camarillo, the January record high and July record are the same. October has the all time max, 106 on 10/23/17. https://t.co/Bx0XjFKDjq

tweet:
@mikealbeland Yes. The Marine layer is strongest in May/June, (June gloom) and weakest in October/November (Santa Ana winds) 

The ridges of high pressure this summer have just been so strong, the air coming off the ocean heats up quick and gets over 90F just 15 miles inland.

tweet: @mikealbeland Yep... onshore flow off the cool Pacific has kept us smoke free and kept temperatures down. Only the 4th hottest June in 114 years of weather record keeping. Inland, the #1 spot was crushed.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet: @mikealbeland Not really. We were able to keep the smoke out as much as possible. Smoke always  began to clear around mid-morning and AQI dropped below 200 by about 4 PM, but would return at sunset and be back to 600+ by 9 PM.... lasting through the night.

The best chance we had for an 80F+ low was October 24, 2017. It was about 73F at midnight at the start of the day, but by 3 AM, it was already over 90°F (yes, it warmed 17+ degrees in the middle of the night) (Reason: Santa Anas)

The high that day was 106.5F.

tweet: @JSGrossman The color coding is based on temperature so the viewer can understand things more clearly. Each color represents 5 degrees. So yellow is anything between 65.0 and 69.9, while light orange is everything from 70.0 to 74.9.

An October day with an AVERAGE temp of 90... (that was on the 24th no less.)

July 2021 having no sub-90 days... or any 100F+ days. Odd.

Feb 2016 being hotter than any March or April. 

Coolest high temp occurred in... November?

July 2018 sucked.

tweet:
The next day was on track to be 119°F... but an ash cloud from a nearby wildfire interrupted our temperature rise at 2 PM, and temps peaked at 115°F.

So while our RECORDED all time record is only 115°F, our hottest possible temperature is higher.

117°F in Vegas? WAY too low.

name: Edgar McGregor
description: Climate science undergrad at @SJSU 📈 21yo climate activist✊ #ActuallyAutistic 🎧 #EarthCleanUp TreeDad🌵🌳 He/Him 🌎 Because the future is worth fighting for.☀
tweet:
In 2018, my area broke our all time record high from 2010 with a high of 113°F. It was hot... but there was onshore flow! It TOTALLY could have been hotter.

In 2020, my area once again broke our all time record. One day was forecasted to be 115°F... and it was.
